lines.text: To have a brain is not a sin, but to have a brain and not use it, that is a sin.
How will they ever be included if they can't ever read or write English.
I quite agree with you, P.K. But at the end of the day, it's only about a dozen people you're talking about teaching. How much difference will that really make?
A waterfall begins from only one drop of water, sir. Look what comes from that...
Little beat big when little smart. First with the head, then with the heart. You can remember that?

It is the best reference library ever, which is a good thing to have. But also from it comes original thought. In school you will get all filled up with the facts. Out here, your brain will learn where to look, how to look, and how to think. Any question you ever have, the answer you will find in Nature - if you know where to look, and how to ask. And then you will have for yourself all the brains that have ever been.
You know, my donkey, Beethoven, once told me a remedy of curing sadness in little boys. Would you like to try it?
[P.K nods]
Okay, stand up, on this brick wall, stand on one leg, good, now close your eyes, say three times "absoloodle".
Absoloodle, absoloodle, absoloodle.
Feel better?
[P.K shakes his head]
No? I guess it proves one thing then.
What's that?
Never take advice from a donkey.
his health, and a good education. He said my health was good, but that my education needed immediate attention. Doc showed me Africa. He made Africa my classroom.
Any question you ever have, the answer you will find in nature.
Any ideology that needs to attack the thing that least threatens it is an ideology that will not outlive its own generation.
Laws define rights.
I agree, sir. But do they always define justice?
Justice, young man, is only relative to who is in charge.
Quite true, sir. But perhaps how well they stay in charge is only relative to how well they dispense that justice.
[last lines]

I remember my nanny would tell me, that if I listened to the wind, I would hear the voices of my life. I listened, and heard Doc talk about justice. I heard Geel Piet talk about hope. I heard Daboola Manzi, the odd medicine man, talk about courage. I heard Maria. These are the voices of my life, the voices of Africa. These are the voices I carry with me, as Duma and I set out together to help bring our country closer to a good tomorrow.
[the African inmates are singing a song in Zulu, insulting the prison guards. One of the guards caught up with Piet and asks him what they are singing about]
What are they singing?

[translating]
They run this way. They run that way. They are confused. They are afraid.
We are afraid?
[shouts]
We are afraid?
You are cowards.
You *bastards*.
A month later, war broke out in Europe. This caused me more problems than bed wetting ever had.
Where did you learn to box like that?
Prison, sir.
Are you training to be a boxer or a comedian?
If you had the opportunity to get to know me, would you take it?
Yah, I would.
Even if it meant going against your father's orders?
What do you call this?
I was branded an idiot by everyone I knew.
They knew you well.
History disputes you.
History takes too long.
Yes I know it does, but it's never kind to those who try to hurry it.
Now, Piss Kop, let's box, eh?
I'm not finished with you... or the Marais girl.
You are a bunch of shit eaters, aren't you, Kaffir?
No, Baas.
What you say?
Yes, Baas.
Bloody right.
You're disrupting the sanctity of the church!
No, you are, Rooinek, with your damn race mixing ideas.
[first lines]

In the 1680s, Dutch, French and Germans fled religious persecution in Europe and settled in Southern Africa. They called themselves the Afrikaners. White Africans. / For the next 250 years, the British Empire fought the Afrikaners for control of the land, the gold and 20 million Native Africans. / In 1948, a conservative Afrikaner government was voted into power. A system of segregation first introduced by the English was declared the law of the land. / The English never gave the system a name. The Afrikaners called it Apartheid. / Our story begins 18 years earlier, in 1930, on a small English farm in South Africa.
You know what P.K stands for? Piss Kop. Piss Head.
No it doesn't. It stands for Peter Phillip Kenneth Keith, that's my name.
Let's piss on the Piss Kop.
You can't hide from me forever, Kaffir. Your day will come and it will be as black as your bloody soul. I promise you.
Damn belief. I believe in Africa. I believe in my people. I want to in the future. Now what do you believe in, P.K.? Tell me, what?
Mind your mouth, Kaffir!
It makes no difference at all!

You can't ignore the fact that the man's the intellectual darling of the National Party! He's got as much use for an English boy rutting after his beautiful Afrikaaner daughter as the Queen has for boules... Pardon my French!
You may be the Heavyweight Champion of our country, but you're a disgrace to it.
You ruin the country, you bastard. You and that Marais bitch!
